channel.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description:
World News: TOI brings the latest world news headlines, Current International
        breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: A Turkish parliamentary committee resumes debate on Sweden's Nato bid

description.#text:
The Turkish
            parliament's foreign affairs committee is deliberating on Sweden's bid to join Nato.
            President Erdogan linked Sweden's admission to US approval of Turkey's request to
            purchase F-16 fighter jets. Erdogan called for simultaneous actions by the US Congress
            and Turkish parliament on these matters. He also urged Canada and other Nato allies to
            lift arms embargoes on Turkey. Ratification process for Sweden's membership has stalled
            in the Turkish parliament due to concerns over security and issues that need
            clarification. Sweden and Finland joined Nato following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

item.title:
Thousands of Chinese migrants cross border as US Marks 80th anniversary of repeal of
            exclusion act

description.#text:
As the US marks the
            80th anniversary of the repeal of the Chinese Exclusion Act, thousands of Chinese
            immigrants are crossing the US-Mexico border after witnessing a decline in the Chinese
            economy. From January through September, over 24,000 Chinese migrants crossed the border
            without authorization, about 13 times the number recorded during the same period last
            year. Chinese migrants who cross into the US without authorization usually wait for
            agents from the US Border Patrol to pick them up. Chinese migrants were granted asylum
            nearly 67% of the time in immigration courts over the past two decades.

item.title:
Lose a limb or risk death? Growing numbers among Gaza's thousands of war-wounded face
            hard decisions

description.#text:
Doctors in Gaza face
            a lack of vascular surgeons and proper treatment due to Israeli airstrikes, resulting in
            an increase in amputations. The acute lack of medical supplies and overcrowding in
            hospitals has forced many to have limbs amputated. The conflict has left Gaza's health
            system overwhelmed, with thousands of people displaced and basic supplies scarce. The
            risk of post-op infections is high due to poor hygiene and limited resources. Many
            amputees struggle to adjust to their new lives. Shaimaa Nabahin, an ambitious university
            student, hopes to leave Gaza and install a prosthetic limb to live a normal life.

item.title: Taiwan man charged over voter trips to China ahead of election

description.#text:
A Taiwanese man has
            been charged with violating election and anti-infiltration laws for arranging sponsored
            visits to China ahead of Taiwan's pivotal poll in January. Officials have warned of
            China's influence on voters and its pressure on Taiwan. The man belongs to a pro-Beijing
            civic group and was funded by an infiltration source to promote candidates and provide
            unfair benefits to voters. The opposition Kuomintang party, known as the 'pan-blue'
            camp, is supported by Chinese authorities.

item.title: Right to protest is under threat in Britain, undermining democracy

description.#text:
For holding a sign
            outside a courthouse reminding jurors of their right to acquit defendants, a retiree
            faces up to two years in prison. For hanging a banner reading Just Stop Oil off a
            bridge, an engineer got a three-year prison sentence. Just for walking slowly down the
            street, scores of people have been arrested. They are among hundreds of environmental
            activists arrested for peaceful demonstrations in the UK, where tough new laws restrict
            the right to protest. The Conservative government says the laws prevent extremist
            activists from hurting the economy and disrupting daily life.

item.title: Ukraine claims destruction of major Russian navy vessel in Crimea

description.#text:
Ukraine's air force
            said on Tuesday that it had destroyed a major Russia landing ship stationed in the
            Crimean waters, after the Russian-installed governor of Crimea said that Kyiv's assault
            sparked a fire in the port of Feodosia. "And the fleet in Russia is getting smaller and
            smaller! Thanks to the Air Force pilots and everyone involved for the filigree work!"
            the commander of Ukraine's air force, Mykola Oleshchuk, said on the Telegram messaging
            app, without providing evidence.

item.title: Indonesia nickel plant explosion death toll rises to 18

description.#text:
The death toll from
            the explosion at a Chinese-funded nickel-processing plant in Indonesia has risen to 18.
            The incident has raised concerns about working conditions at Beijing's investment
            facilities. The explosion occurred during repairs on a furnace when residual slag came
            in contact with flammable materials. The majority of the victims suffered burns to over
            70% of their bodies. This is not the first incident at facilities funded by Chinese
            companies, raising further concerns about safety.

item.title: China expects searing heat, more weather extremes in 2024

description.#text:
China's National
            Climate Center predicts that China will experience scorching heat and an increase in
            extreme weather next year due to the El Nino weather phenomenon. This year, China
            experienced some of its hottest temperatures on record as well as a severe cold snap.
            The chief expert of China's National Climate Center warns that 2024 may be even hotter
            and bring more frequent and powerful extreme weather events. This past summer, Beijing
            experienced record heat and a remote township in northwest China recorded the hottest
            temperature on record. Typhoons also caused widespread flooding in China's north.

item.title: Israel PM says Hamas must be destroyed for peace

description.#text:
Israeli Prime
            Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vows to continue fighting in Gaza until Hamas is destroyed,
            defying calls for a ceasefire as concerns rise over the potential spread of the conflict
            amidst US-Iran tensions. Netanyahu dismisses speculation of a halt to the fighting and
            emphasizes the need for military pressure to free remaining hostages held by Hamas.
            Israeli operations intensify, resulting in a rising death toll and increased airstrikes.
            Meanwhile, diplomatic efforts for a ceasefire have been rejected by Hamas and Islamic
            Jihad, who are also holding hostages.

item.title: China unveils a new naval chief as maritime tensions climb

description.#text:
China unveils new
            head of navy, Hu Zhongming, promoted to general in Beijing ceremony attended by
            President Xi Jinping. Hu is now commander of the largest navy by number of vessels. Dong
            Jun, the head of the navy in 2021, also attended the ceremony. Tensions rise in South
            China Sea and Taiwan Strait as China flexes its muscles. Chinese military holds major
            drills around Taiwan and vows to bring Taiwan under Beijing's control. Wang Wenquan is
            the new political commissar of the Southern Theater Command.

item.title: 'Taiwan not seeing signs of large-scale Chinese military act pre-election'

description.#text:
Taiwan is not seeing
            any signs of large-scale Chinese military activity before elections next month but is
            keeping a close watch on China, the island's defence ministry said on Tuesday. As the
            election approaches Taiwan has been reporting Chinese fighter jets and warships around
            the island, as well as balloons crossing the sensitive Taiwan Strait, though the
            military says they are most likely for weather monitoring purposes. Taiwan's defence
            ministry gives a daily update on Chinese military activities near the island, including
            how many aircraft it has detected.

item.title: US strikes sites used by Iran-backed forces in retaliation to attack on troops

description.#text:
The US military
            conducted targeted air strikes in Iraq in response to a drone attack by Iran-aligned
            militias. President Biden authorized the precision air strikes to hold accountable those
            responsible for attacks on coalition forces. General Michael Erik Kurilla stated that
            the strikes aimed to degrade militants' ability to continue such attacks. The
            retaliatory strikes likely resulted in casualties among Kataib Hezbollah militants and
            the destruction of facilities used by the group. The drone attack targeted a military
            base used by US and anti-jihadist coalition forces.

item.creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: In a first, Hindu woman files nomination in Pakistan general elections

description.#text:
Saveera Parkash, a
            member of the Hindu community in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa's Buner district, has officially
            filed nomination papers to contest a general seat in the upcoming Pakistan general
            elections. Running under the banner of the Pakistan People's Party (PPP), Parkash
            follows in the footsteps of her father, Oam Parkash, a retired doctor and dedicated PPP
            member. She is the first woman from Buner to vie for a general seat and has highlighted
            the historical neglect and suppression of women in the region.

item.creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Pakistan president Alvi approves removal of PM's adviser Ahad Cheema

description.#text:
President Arif Alvi
            approved the removal of advisor Ahad Cheema on the instruction of ECP. The removal was
            sought by advocate Syed Azizuddin Kakakhel to ensure transparent elections. ECP ruled
            that Cheema's removal was reasonable to prevent his influence on elections. Cheema's
            immediate removal was ordered by ECP. The petition also seeks the removal of Anwarul Haq
            Kakar, Fawad Hasan Fawad, and Syed Tauqir Hussain Shah. The plea stated that the
            involvement of these individuals in the caretaker government would compromise the
            transparency of the upcoming elections.

item.title: 'Israel economy to shrink 2% as war sidelines workers'

description.#text:
The Israeli economy
            is expected to shrink by 2% this quarter due to the war with Hamas, leading to a spike
            in unemployment. About 900,000 people were called up to fight, resulting in a
            significant portion of the work force being missing from the labor market. The number of
            people filing for unemployment benefits since the start of the war is 191,666. The
            tourism, construction and agriculture sectors are experiencing severe labor shortages,
            as Palestinian workers have been barred from entering Israel.

item.title: In Christmas Day message, pope decries Gaza's 'appalling harvest' of civilian deaths

description.#text:
Pope Francis
            delivers Christmas message, highlighting children dying in wars, Israeli strikes in
            Gaza, and the abominable attack by Hamas militants. He calls for an end to conflicts in
            Ukraine, Syria, Yemen, Lebanon, Armenia, and Azerbaijan, and defends the rights of
            migrants. Francis criticizes the armaments industry and calls for investigation into the
            rise of arms production, sales, and trade. He emphasizes the need for dialogue and
            international support for a two-state solution in Israel and Palestine.

item.title: US judge okays suit against X over unpaid bonuses to go on

description.#text:
A federal judge has
            allowed a lawsuit against social media company X to proceed. The lawsuit, filed by Mark
            Schobinger, a former senior director of compensation for Twitter, claims that the
            company promised but never paid millions of dollars in bonuses. Schobinger alleges that
            Twitter orally promised employees 50% of their 2022 targeted bonuses if they stayed with
            the company in the first quarter of 2023. The judge ruled that Schobinger had plausibly
            stated a breach of contract claim under California law. The judge also determined that
            California law governed the case, rejecting Twitter's arguments.

item.title: For Ukrainians, Christmas comes early, but not a moment too soon

description.#text:
Ukraine's Ukrainian
            Orthodox Church switched from the Julian church calendar to celebrate Christmas on
            December 25, aligning with most of Europe and distancing itself from Russia's tradition.
            The shift brought joy to families, who celebrated the holiday earlier and exchanged
            presents. The change is seen as a step toward Europe and away from Russia's influence.
            Most parishes in the Ukrainian Orthodox Church followed the recommendation to change the
            date, with only a few still adhering to the Julian calendar.

item.title: Attacks kill at least 160 people in central Nigeria

description.#text:
Armed groups have
            killed at least 160 people in central Nigeria in a series of attacks on villages, local
            government officials said on Monday. "As many as 113 persons have been confirmed killed
            as Saturday hostilities persisted to early hours of Monday," Monday Kassah, head of the
            local government in Bokkos, Plateau State, told AFP. Military gangs, locally called
            "bandits", launched "well-coordinated" attacks in "not fewer than 20 different
            communities" and torched houses, Kassah said.

item.title:
Ukraine celebrates Christmas on December 25 for the first time, distancing itself
            from Russia

description.#text:
Christmas in Ukraine
            carries more weight this year as the country observes it as a public holiday on Dec. 25,
            reflecting their national identity and opposition to the Russian invasion. Ukraine's
            predominantly Orthodox Christian faith is divided between two churches, one of which had
            long affiliation with the Russian Orthodox Church. The change to Dec. 25 was embraced by
            many Ukrainians as a move towards historical justice and the traditions of their
            country. Celebrations took place in various locations, including an open-air museum in
            Kyiv and the village of Kryvorivnia.
